title: Thursday, 26th April, 2018

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Most of the sellside I have to hand is just a summary of the figures, such as UBS.

BE11:20am

Upstream reported a disappointing post-tax profit of $1,551m vs cons of $1,886m (UBSe $1,753m; we expect NAM had an impact). Integrated Gas earnings of $2,439m beat cons $1,881m (UBSe $1,903m) on strong trading results and a healthy LNG market. Production was 3.839Mboe/d vs UBSe at 3.79Mboe/d. Downstream earnings were $1,687m, below cons of $1,940m (UBSe $1,980m) on weak results in the Refining & Trading segment. Oil Product earnings were $1,002m vs cons $1,352m (UBSe $1,360m) and Chemicals earnings were $685m vs. cons $599m (UBSe $620m).

BE11:21am

(@Dec69: incrementally, yes.)

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Shell's CEO noted that the current FCF outlook is consistent with the company's $25bn 2018-20 share buyback plan. Integrated Gas production is expected to be up 140-160kboe/d y/y in 2Q on maintenance, with LNG liquefaction volumes flat over the same period. Upstream production for 2Q is expected to fall 230-250kboe/d on portfolio impacts and maintenance. In 2Q refinery availability is seen falling y/y on maintenance; Chemicals availability is expected to rise. Corporate results are expected to be a net charge of $300-350m in 2Q18 while 2018 guidance remains at ~$1.4-1.6bn.
Valuation: Buy, PT 2,675p/share
PT (at $60/bbl) incorporates benefit for improved capital productivity. It implies a divi yield of 5.3% and a 2019 FCF yield (at our forecast oil price of $65/bbl) of 9.1%.

But hey, since I mention CS pushing the UK, here's that.

BE11:34am

The UK ranks as the second cheapest major region after Japan,
with its composite valuation score in the bottom decile of its historic range, and the dividend yield relative to the market back to a 15-year high. Using HOLT ® , the additional discount rate priced into UK equities vs Continental Europe is close to all-time highs. Almost all the major sectors, apart from industrials, look unusually cheap on both PE and PB relative to their global peers.

Soundbuy ITV - to see it put on 2% is a rarity these days...
Pharma @rw42, and what a shock to learn that the routers ("rooters"?) in question were made by ZTE
BE11:34am

The three major drivers for the relative performance of the UK markets are oil (16% of market cap), GEM (which accounts for around 20% of non-commodity sales, the highest of any non-GEM region), and lead indicators, which, when they fall, tend to support the UK's relative performance given it has the lowest cyclical weighting of the major regions and low operational leverage. UK equities have significantly decoupled from all three drivers.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Sterling strength a risk but is only "only modestly cheap", CS says. Here's what they're buying.

Maverick Talking of CS they gave a very good conference call and presentation this morning on the Takeda/Shire story, noting how we are yet to hear from Roche and Pfizer for both they feel a Shire T/O to be affordable and make strategic sense.
BE11:35am

GDP growth is likely to be a bit stronger than consensus this
year (1.8% vs consensus at 1.6%). We went overweight UK banks in October given attractive valuation, more rate hikes likely than the market has priced and a consolidated industry structure: Lloyds and Barclays. UK retailing looks extremely cheap vs global peers despite disruption being more advanced: ABF & KGF. Internationally, we find big cap oil (the UK sector has a FCF yield of 7.5%), big cap mining (FCF yield of c9%), tobacco (BAT) and spirits (Diageo) all unusually cheap vs global peers for little obvious reason. The following stocks look cheap vs global peers, the market, on HOLT, and have positive earnings revisions: Shell, Glencore, Aviva, EasyJet and Carnival.

As in, the ITV licence holder north of the border. Here's Liberum:

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Stating that national TV ad revenues (which is the closest comp for ITV) is up +1% in Q1 as expected. For the 5 months to the end of May, it is stating this will be -2% but will be +ve for 1H because of the World Cup. A few points from this (1) -2% to May after +1% for Q1 suggests April May down 6.5% across the two months. If April is down 12%-13%, in line with what media buyers suggested ITV would be, that implies May is flat and (2) STV national TV ad revenues tend to generally (not always) under-perform ITV Plc.s ad revenues, part because it does not have ITV's digital channels such as ITV2, 3 etc and part because of how its advertising is sold. On the whole, though, statement should provide reassurance that Q1 has performed as expected and that April May do not look worse than what the market always thinks.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

The weakness in the Swedish Krone sees us upgrade our FY estimates by 3.5%. This puts our Q2 EPS c.4% ahead of consensus largely on FX (-120bp gross margin and 12.8% EBIT margin). Given the c.20% bounce in the share price off the lows we believe this is largely in the price but there remains an upside risk of improvement momentum in a heavily out of favour stock. We also note the better weekly German sales data (in the last two weeks and easy May comps) and the potential for the T-Mall launch in China to boost the sales performance but we believe the combination of a very weak March and clearance of excess inventory will continue to weigh on LFL sales and maintain our 2Q -3% LFL.

BE11:53am

They're sellers.

BE11:53am

The main upside risks to our Sell thesis other than LFL sales are:
1) Store refurbishments seeing a bigger sales uplift (we don’t expect evidence of this yet) and are accelerated (again unlikely as we think RFID and new distribution centres are needed first); 2) A radical store closure or cost saving plan is announced (whilst necessary in our view on over 5 years we see limited acceptance of this view to date); 3)The inventory is cleared quickly allowing new season product to flow to stores more efficiently (possible but management seems intent on balancing the sales impact v profit rather than aggressively clearing inventory).

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Valuation an issue but upgrade TP to SEK110 (from 105)— Even with an earnings upgrade the c.16x FY18 PE is a stumbling block for a company where we struggle to see the route for earnings growth. With a 3.5% EPS upgrade we maintain our 12x cyclical retail multiple but increase the TP on the earnings.

BE11:57am

Nokia reported results that significantly missed SME. cons on both revenues and EBIT, in the context of c.25% stock price outperformance YTD vs. EU Tech (+7% vs Ericsson). While the company has reiterated its objectives for 2018 and 2020 profit, and posted a beat in the smaller Technologies (patents) business, Networks Sales/EBIT missed. The weaker than expected revenue in Networks is largely driven by softness in N. America (whereas Ericsson saw this region as strong), and this is expected to persist in 2Q. While the company raised its growth expectation for the total Networks addressable market (fixed and wireless), and now thinks it will take share (prior guide for in line), this (along with reiterated FY profit objectives) would suggest a significantly back end loaded year. Moreover, while Networks margin guidance was reiterated for FY18, and a significant group gross margin miss was driven by regional and product mix rather than product weakness, NOK will invest an extra €100mn in Opex for 5G trials. While Wireless faced tough comps, revenues were down 18% yoy (10% constant FX; ERIC Networks was down 2%). While the company has highlighted a strong order pipeline and that 5G is accelerating, we look for further clarity on expected re-acceleration in 2H.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Nokia raised its FY18 Networks market outlook to 1%-3% declines (constant currency) vs 2%-4% declines prior given an improved market conditions in 2H, especially in N. America. The company now expects to grow faster than this market growth rate (v.s performing in line prior) given market share gain opportunities in several areas such as 4G, 5G, IP Routing and Optical. We positively view updated commentary from the company that commercial 5G deployments will begin in late 2018 vs. prior expectation of beginning in 2019, but note that NOK now expects to incur an additional €100mn-€200mn of temporary expenses related to delivering 5G customer trials (vs. prior expectations of an additional €100mn). We see the improved market outlook as an incremental positive for Nokia and Ericsson. Despite expected weakness in its Networks business in 1H, NOK reiterated its FY18 Networks EBIT margin guidance of 6%-9% and its FY20 expectations of 9%-12% as it expects a rebound in 2H, and stated it has a solid order pipeline.
Nokia continues to expect its recurring cash flow to improve over the long term but we note that 1Q saw worse than expected cash flow driven by lower profitability. The company also reiterated that it is on track to deliver the full €1.2bn of recurring annual cost savings it targets in FY18.

BE12:01pm

Hastings released its Q1 2018 trading statement this morning. Similar to FY17 results, Q1 18 showed decent year-on-year progress but does not feel like a ‘beat and raise’ quarter with a slowdown in growth and higher claims costs than expected.

Forester @fatdaz indeed - offshore wind!!!
Maverick 1Q Net pft $550.6M
BE12:01pm

For the twelve-month period to 31 March, gross written premiums increased 16% year-on-year. However, Q1 18 was up 5% showing a slowdown in the growth trajectory for the year. Compared to our 10% top-line expectation for the year, Q1 18 is below our expectations for growth.

Hastings increased customer numbers 10% year-on-year but looking at Q1 18 on Q4 17, customer policy numbers increased just over 1%. Net revenue however increased 12% to £184.5m likely driven by higher other revenues in our view.

BE12:01pm

Hastings reiterated that trading had been challenging in the first two months of the year. But since then trading has improved and it remains on target to hit its 3 million customer goal during 2019.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Hastings pointed to snow and icy conditions in the first quarter leading to higher claims costs than expected. Despite this, the company is confident of delivering a calendar year loss ratio below or within the target range of 75-79%.

BE12:02pm

Hastings is a nimble player in a price comparison focused UK motor insurance market. Whilst, we see Hastings as having strong ability in its core markets, we believe that the current valuation already gives the company credit for its data driven approach and near term growth potential.

BE12:02pm

There we go.
